text.0:
:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: Get our fact-checks of the week's most outrageous claims delivered straight to your WhatsApp inbox.

Subscribe in three easy steps:

:link: Click the link https://t.co/0baDsRbvkA
:input_numbers: Save our number
:mobile_phone: Send a message with your name. https://t.co/RjMKuJrAgV
text.1:
A WhatsApp message saying KFC is giving away 3,000 snack buckets in :Kenya: is :cross_mark: FALSE.

:poultry_leg: The scam asks you to first share the message with 20 friends to win: https://t.co/D1sM8sCFbN
text.2:
A photo of Cristiano Ronaldo wearing a beret with the logo of Uganda's People Power Movement is ALTERED.

:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: The original photo shows the footballer without any headwear: https://t.co/ZXYBxNPftm
text.3:
A Facebook post claiming to show Tanzania's new railway is PARTLY FALSE.

:bullet_train: The post uses a mix of images including some from other countries: https://t.co/6rFGhU2Gwe
text.4:
From @Cristiano Ronaldo allegedly showing support for a political party in :Uganda: to @kfc giving away thousands of free meals to WhatsApp users in :Kenya:, it's been another busy week of fact-checking dubious claims.

:newspaper: Here are some of our top stories from the past seven days:
